references: Tilley, S. C. 1985. Desmognathus imitator. Cat. Am. Amph.Rep. 359.1-359.2.

Martof, B. S., W. M. Palmer, J. R. Bailey, and J. R. Harrison, III. 1980. Amphibians and reptiles of the Carolinas and Virginia. University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, North Carolina. 264 pp.
Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.
habitat_description: Desmognathus imitator is primarily found in cool, moist, mid- to high-elevation hardwood and red spruce-Fraser fir forests.  These salamanders will occupy borders of seeps and springs, as well as the moist forest floor and wet rock surfaces in the vicinity of streams (Petranka 1998).  Intermittent stream heads and moist cove reaches just above permanent streams are also suitable as habitat (Martof et al. 1980).  This salamander is endemic to Great Smoky mountains of Tennessee and North Carolina, with populations possibly occurring in the neighboring Plott Balsam mountains in North Carolina (Petranka 1998).
